reviewText:
Gist of the story
Moving to a new house means that you might have some difficulty acclimating to your new environment, especially if you’re a little kid. It’s hard enough to make friends in an already unfamiliar neighborhood so what is little Emily to do when she’s in this exact predicament. Perhaps, she’ll find friendship in the most unlikely “people.” With the discovery of three dolls ( well, 1 little girl doll, 1 puppet thing and a clown doll…thing) in her new house’s basement, these seemingly inanimate objects creeps their way into this little girl’s heart and they all become good buddies. It’s a happily ever after, right?

Right?

Then, why was Emily’s parents driven to the point where they felt the need to sequester their daughter and her pals in the basement, where they are out of sight, out of mind?

“They will never take my friends away from me.” -Emily

It’s strange that Emily’s parents disappear soon afterwards.

What? Someone ordered pizza from Emily’s house?

Good luck, pizza guy.

;)

---

Gameplay
The game consists of surviving a of couple nights inside what seems like a recently vacated house. You play as a pizza delivery man and unfortunately you are now in the company of one little psychotic girl and her possessed dollies. Emily’s three besties chases you around the house for some reason and avoiding them becomes tedious and downright exhausting at times.

When the clock strikes midnight, this is the time when Em’s first doll, Kiki, comes out to play. Kiki likes the attention and even if the game tells you not to look at her, you really need to keep your eye on her because she will grab and choke…I mean hug you to death if you avert your eyes away from her. She’s just full of love. When you hear her giggling, it’s best to search around for her so you know which direction she’s coming from and ready yourself for a light jog. This is important when her friendos join the fray later on.

Once the first hour is over, we are introduced to Mr. Tatters, a cute little clown that loves an audience so much that he’ll kill you if you don’t stick around. Once again, the game will warn you to “Please stay still” when Tatters is around but never believe the warnings, especially when there’s a winky face involve. Tatters want you to stand still and touch your warm, soft…pizza bread. Like Emily, listen for his laugh so you know when to stop and his disappointed groans when you didn’t run away from him.

Oh, did I mention Kiki is there? Just pray you don’t get a Kiki spawn at the same time you hear Tatter’s laugh.

The next hour is with Chester. Marvelous, he is not. Like the previous hours, you’ll have Chester and his other joker friends hunting you down. If you guessed that the game tells you not to run away from Chester, then you guessed right. Definitely get out of dodge. He looks like a puppet…that moves without any help. There’s nothing eventful there, really. Until you reach the next hour and have the three stooges and Emily gang up on you.

The technique is really simply. Just run around through the house, in circles and never stop running, unless you hear the clown.
---

Did ya scare me?
The scare factor of this game, on the scale of 1-10, I rate Emily Wants to Play a 4 out of 10. 4 being, “the game tries.”

I must admit, the game genuinely creep me out at the beginning. When I saw the unmoving figure of Tatters hunched over by the corner, my “NOPE” senses were tingling. I really thought I would be giving it a higher scare factor score. The introduction of the game sets up the atmosphere really well. However, after figuring out what I should be doing to counter Emily & friends, the urge to fire up Dark Souls so that I can shove my rapier in an innocent undead soldier out of frustration swelled within me.

The creepy vibe starts to dwindle away by the 20 minute mark. All that was left were the jumpscares, unnecessarily loud ones.

The game is mostly silent and besides ambient noises like doors creaking open, it stays quiet the entire time. Doors and lights also randomly open/close occasionally, which was confusing at first but whoever is doing that just loves to troll. I think Kiki is responsible for these occurrences…or maybe it was just the wind.

---

Graphics and Technical Issues
The game isn’t the most upstanding, graphic wise, but it does its job enough. There are few graphical options to choose from but for some reason, I had a hard time selecting the resolution. The resolution sometimes changes when I (alt)(tab). Clicking my native resolution wouldn’t register. It’s happened only a few times but I thought it was worth mentioning.

Emily Wants to Play crashed about 6x for me in the past 2 hours of gameplay. At one point, I couldn’t even click NG without it crashing. I am also reading in the Steam Community forums that some players are having problems launching the game. It hasn’t been addressed (not to my knowledge) but hopefully it will be in the future.

---

My observations
I had my fingers crossed that Emily Wants to Play will keep me on the edge the entire time but that’s not what happened. It got a little annoying and although I was almost terrified to proceed onwards (b/c I saw a clown and a little girl doll..thing), I’m glad I did. I knew annoyance will always triumph whatever fear I felt at the start. I love overcoming obstacles.

---

Wrap Up
It’s an okay game with a sad story scattered around for the players to piece together. It’s not exactly a FNAF clone since it does have its own thing. If you have an extra 5 bucks lying around and you like quick bursts of jumpscares that will last about 30 minutes then get this game.

---

TL;DR
Pros:
-The beginning sets up the atmosphere
- Creepy at times
- Sounds are timed well
- Sad but interesting storyline
- Clown doll…thing
- Dolls in general

Cons:
- Although the sense of dread was there at the beginning, it flatlines fairly quickly
- Needless trolling when it comes to the game’s mechanics
- Crashes
- Some players are have difficulty launching the game
- Clown doll…thing
- Dolls in general

---

reviewText:
Emily wants to play is a fairly new horror game that has seen some attention by the lets player community, so heres another random persons thoughts on the game

+ The games core monsters all look very clean. I always thought that for a game made by 1 guy, the models actually look pretty nice.

+ Due to the random nature of the game, this game has some replayability, especially doing 5 am over and over again.

+ The game is fairly simple to grasp. It didn't take long for me to find out what each monster does and how to get rid of them

+ As far as the jumpscares, They are all unique and did get me quite a few times. They even use different sounds!

+ The game is actually difficult (especially in the later levels) Which is good because if it was easy, I bet it would of gotten boring fast.

+ The flashlight in this game isn't a complete joke.

- As far as the scare factor goes, I personally didn't find this game that scary. The only thing that really scares me is chester. I personally dont mind because the gameplay is good

- The story is kinda lackluster. I didn't really find myself getting engaged with it like FNaF for example.

- Whenever you die, you have to restart back at the main menu instead of there being a retry button. Kind of a nitpick, but it kind of ruins the flow of the gameplay when I want to skip the main menu/clock animation.

- I kind of wish there was more. But I guess that is a good complaint to have.

OVERALL: Emily wants to play is a fantastic game for horror and non horror fans alike. I feel like its creepy enough to get into, but fun enough to want you to keep playing. I just hope there is a sequal at some point, and thanks to Shawn Hitchcock for making such a fantastic game. Even if there isn't a sequal, I hope whatever you work on in the future is just as good.

reviewText:
Well, what can I say about this game?  As you can see, I haven't played it very much, because it scared the poo out of me!

Most of the derogatory comments I see are 'it's Pewdie-bait' or 'just cheap jump scares' or 'graphics suck'.  And I can give you that last one, the graphics are not cutting edge, it's very much an indie-style game and it shows, lacking a lot of the polish a AAA title would have.

Probably why it's only $5 and not $60.

Yes, it has jump scares, but I find them to be very well done.  The first time I crept through the house and saw dummies moving when I looked away, or lights turn out as soon as I left a room, or some little girl-beast crawling behind some furniture causing me to immediately turn around and leave the room and close the door, it scared the crap out of me.  And those aren't 'jump scares'.  That is building atmosphere.  I felt tense, on edge, creepy... and I hadn't even reached the part of the game where the things attack me, yet.  Might be because I play in the dark with my back to an empty room like a pro.

I got so scared I exited the game before anything actually happened to me, and I'm terrified to try again.  This is EXACTLY what a horror game is supposed to do: scare your pants off.  It's not 'just jump scares'.  If you're an Internet Tough Guy or just hard to scare, if things like The Grudge and The Ring don't freak you out, you probably won't be scared by this game.

Gameplay is pretty simple, you can look around, move, and right-click to activate stuff.  As the night wears on, different 'levels' of murder-dolls come at you, and each is defeated by differing methods you're left to discover these on your own.  There's a few hints lying around the game world, but mostly you're left to try it yourself.  It's not a long game, it's probably not even that difficult, but for only five bucks?  It definitely delivers on the creepy for that.

If you're expecting a polished, exquisite product with great graphics and 10+ hours of gameplay and lots of replayability for five dollars, well... you're kind of silly.  Or spoiled.

For the price, this game gives you exactly what it promises.  So it gets my first ever thumbs up review.

reviewText:
Emily Wants to Play sure is an interesting little game.

It seems to be standard now that all horror games require you to survive from 12 AM to 6 AM, avoiding whatever obligatory monster is thrown at you.

Out of context, that sounds a bit reductive. But for this game and others such as Five Nights at Freddy's, it's really not  THAT  reductive. A lot of what makes this game scary depends on how easily scared you are. A lot of this game is incredibly reliant on jumpscares, which, for better or worse, is where a lot of horror games seem to be.

Emily Wants to Play isn't that different in that regard.

Emily sure does want to play, but man oh man, she won't be telling you any of the rules.

Go into the basement before you find the secret enterance? She'll kill you.
Try to pick up the knife to defend yourself at a certain point? She'll kill you.

PROTIP:  The whiteboard in the kitchen lies to you. Do the exact OPPOSITE of whatever it says.


TL:DR: Kinda samey with other horror games that have come out in recent years, the atmosphere is pretty good though. $4.99 is the absolute threshold I have for games like this, and you shouldn't pay any more for this. If you can get it at a price drop during a sale, sure, go for it.

I give it a 7/10.

I can not recommand this game for several reasons. Review may contain spoilers. You have been warned.

First of, the game isn't necessarly bad, but the game is pretty terrible based on my own preferences.

Pros:

- Creepy at first
- Freedom to explore

Cons:

- Small map
- Obvious scares
- Ridiciously difficult to survive (for me anyway)
- Cliché and uninspired story-line
- Very basic level design


This is what happened when I played:

I enter the house and start exploring. I see a few scares here and there, most of them obvious onces, like a stalking doll, or a doll that gave me a jumpscare when I walked up to it. Scares every horror gamer out there have seen a thousand times before.

I read a couple of notes from, what I guess is Emily. She feels like her parents never loved her and now she is haunting the house. I listen to a couple of cassettes from her mother that apparently delt with psychological problems, basic horror story settings. Nothing very intresting.

Then, the clock tics and I notice it's midnight. From nowhere, a doll jumps at my screen and kills me. Game over...

I restart from latest checkpoint and decide to move away from the killer doll. Apparently, she followed me and killed me again. Game over.

I restart from the latest checkpoint again, knowing how to deal with the doll this time, or so I thought. The doll only moved when I wasn't looking, so I was constantly looking her way to assure she wouldn't kill me again. I entered a room and closed the door. Apparently, she could teleport past the door and killed me yet again. Game over.

I restarted from last checkpoint again. This time, I decided to pretty much run around so that ♥♥♥♥♥ wouldn't catch me. I ran into a room I had not yet been in. A second doll appeared out of nowhere and killed me instead. This time I gave up and turned off the game.

I died 5 times in less than 10 minutes.


Maybe I'm doing something wrong, maybe I gave up too easily, I don't know, but this game was just too frustrating for me. Even without the annoying dolls all around me, the game wasn't intresting. It's way too cliché and offers nothing new to the table, at all. Level design is basic, story is unoriginal, scares are way too overused.

2/10 - Would rage quit again.

Does it have replayability value? Yes. You can play with your friends and poop your pants with them together.

Does it have the 1$/Hr value? Probably, even though I have just done a quick playthrough, there is still much more to do.

Does it have game-breaking bugs? Not that I am aware of, but there are people mentioning that the game is not launching, if that is the case then visit the steam forums!

Does it have a fun factor to it? Well, that depends, if you are into the whole FNAF-sort of game then you will enjoy this one, otherwise you should pass.

non-FNAF friends: 6-7/10

This game is not meant to be a long playthrough, it is meant to be played in short burts, so keep that in mind.

reviewText:
Further reviewed on: https://www.scaredtoplay.com/news/emily-wants-to-play-review

Pizza delivery people should get hazard pay for all the nonsense they deal with, including here. Emily Wants to Play sees the player attempting to deliver an invisible pizza and being subsequently trapped in the house with a lovely little girl and her three dolls.

The player must move around, keep themselves in lit areas (preferably) and avoid all the dolls, plus Emily herself come midnight and onward until the early morning. Each doll has a strategy to them, and with all three out it is sure to be fantastically frustrating.

The pros:

- Pretty nice looking game
- Sound effects are crisp and add tension as well as audible aids against enemies
- The dolls being able to interact with the light switches and doors is an interesting idea and used well
- Hints at a somewhat interesting story here and there

The cons:

- Jumpscare heavy. This is eased once the player learns the strategies and patterns to each doll, but they are still very much so in your face and obnoxious
- The opening theme is almost note for note taken from The Grudge
- Unclear objectives initially. The dolls have hints to them in the house, to some degree, but the rest is essentially left up to the play to wonder about and probably die a few times
- Story and gameplay aren't really anything all that deep or new

Conclusions:

Emily Wants to Play is a familiar horror experience with some interesting mechanics mixed in. While it may lose any tension after the few jumpscares and suffer from a lack of direction, it is a fun little horror game to play through for anyone looking for a decent horror game or a few jumpscares.

reviewText:
Oh, wow. Let me tell you. I haven't been this jumpy in a long time. The scares in this game are excellent and the concept is amazing.

Twitch LIVE Gameplay Highlight - Twitch.tv/halios00
Live play of the game - Warning, Language is sometimes pretty strong.

Story
You are a pizza delivery guy. You get a call for a large pepperoni with anchovies to a home. Normal order, normal place, right? Yeah, that's what they want you to think. You arrive to a home that the front door is wide open. You peek in and yell to see if anyone is home. That's when your night starts. When it ends, Emily will decide.


Graphics
Not the greatest. I don't believe the developers were going for futuristic graphics when they made this game. They made everything detailed but not cutting edge.


Sound
.....yea, they got this one pretty much perfect. God, I hate these noises.


Setting
Very creepy. The house is boxed up here and there, like the family is moving and makes for tense moments when you are trying to move quickly through the house. The home is small but seems huge when a scary moment is happening.


Mood
Tense and scary. They captured the feeling of uncertainty and the pressure of fighting for your life beautifully.


Replayability
You WILL lose. And lose. And lose. Then you will start to understand how things work and start to succeed. Once you beat it, it would be fun to go back and show friends or beat again.


Final Say
The premise, mood, and general feeling you get from this game is excellent. It's been a long time since I've felt this crazy tension that hits you the moment the game starts and it never ceases. It actually intensifies near the end, when impossible odds are placed against you. This live action Five Nights at Freddys will keep you guessing and jumping until the final credits.


Final Score - 8/10

Welcome to Jumpscare TownPopulation: You
Emily Wants To Play is a very simple horror game with a Five Night's At Freddy's feel to it. There are no real instructions which leads you to discover things on your own. If you don't enjoy jump scares then you don't need to play this game.

We played this game (3 dudes) while taking turns and watching each other's reactions. It can be fun if you up the stakes with a punishment for losing (eating gross flavoured jelly beans is our personal favorite). For a few dollars and an hour of entertainment for three people, it wasn't a bad purchase.

Unlike FNAF, it can be challenging to figure out why exactly you died in-game. We looked up some instructions in the other Steam reviews which immediately killed" the game for us. Without any knowledge it can be frustrating and with all the knowledge you're left with a deflated balloon. Choose carefully whether or not you want to spoil the win conditions for yourself.

I personally couldn't see myself purchasing this game for me alone. Unless you're a very enthusiastic indie horror gamer (or you're streaming your gameplay)

reviewText:
A solid, albeit somewhat bland indie horror game. Very tense, but a bit more polish could have helped.

The game's objective is essentially to survive a 6 hour stay while avoiding encounters with monstrous dolls that have gained a life of their own.
Initially very fun and exciting but in the later sections you might suffer with potentially unwinnable scenarios that frustratingly force you to try it over again. You'll have to pray to RNGesus for a decent shot at winning, it seems.
It's strangely somewhat similar to 5 Nights at Freddy's in that if you want to reach the end, you need to treat the game strategically and keep your wits about you.

reviewText: In this latest installment by Pixar Studios, you play as Pizza Man, delivering your stuffed crust goodness to the new family in the neighborhood.  However, things take a turn for the worse when the police catch you trespassing on private property and the third portion of the game revolves mainly around defending the main character as the side character Phoenix Justice, to prove Pizza Man's innocence.  The game hits many controversial subjects such as lesbianism and child pornography, in a mature manner.  All in all, this is a great game for those with a little more patience for a more serious game the industry sorely needs.
